citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
A female lemur was being individually housed in an indoor housing facility. While reviewing the facilities environment
enhancement plan for NHP it does not appropriately address special considerations for individually housed NHP that
cannot see or hear NHP of its own or compatible species. The environment enhancement plan was approved by the AV
when there were 2 lemurs being housed together but has not been updated since the 2nd lemur was removed. Failure to
provide special attention to individually housed NHPs could result in psychological distress which could negatively affect
their well-being. Facilities must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan as directed by the attending
veterinarian for environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of nonhuman primates.
Correct by 7/12/24.

Multiple maintenance issues were observed during inspection. An elevated shelter/den box (approximately 5.5 feet off the
ground) that a gray fox was sleeping in had flooring that was coming loose and a corner of the flooring was separating
from the walls with the corner flapping/moving as the fox was breathing. The side of a wolf shelter in an enclosure
containing 3 wolves had the back wall coming off. The underground fencing in the arctic fox enclosure was washed out
underneath and there was a gap between the fencing and the ground underneath. The same enclosure also had rabbit
wire with sharp points protruding from it into the enclosure. Screwheads/nailheads were sticking out on the flooring of
various wooden resting platforms in multiple fox and bobcat enclosures. An igloo shelter for an enclosure containing 6
wolves was cracked and had a hole in it.
These maintenance issues create various safety hazards for the animals. The fox could potentially fall through the flooring
of its shelter as its sleeping. Shelter with holes in it or the walls coming off doesn't properly protect the animals from the
elements of the weather. The underground fencing with the gap underneath could potentially cause injury if the arctic fox
stepped through the fencing and got its leg stuck. Sharp points in an enclosure can also cause injury.
All shelter or resting platforms being provided to the animals need to be fixed and maintained so no
screwheads/nailheads or sharp points are sticking out, no walls or floors are falling off of the provided shelters, and no
animals can stick their limbs through the underground fencing as they walk through their shelter.

The walk-in freezer used to store fresh meat products for the carnivores’ showed signs of significant structural damage
that prevented the freezer from fully closing. There was excessive ice buildup within the freezer further preventing proper
closure and potentially exposing the food products to temperature fluctuations. Failure to provide adequate refrigeration to
perishable food can result in spoilage of food which can cause serious food borne illnesses in the animals. Supplies of
food shall be provided adequate refrigeration by the facility to prevent spoilage and maintain it’s wholesomeness.
At the food donation drop-off site there were three white-tailed deer carcasses in various stages of decomposition. There
were too numerous to count flies on and around the carcasses with two of the carcasses having visible maggots and
exposed body cavities. These donated deer carcasses are intended as food for the carnivores and the facility is not
following their SOP for donated deer meat which requires the carcasses to be cut and immediately stored under
refrigeration. Failure to store the deer carcasses appropriately is allowing for contamination by flies which can
contaminate the meat and spread disease to the animals. The facility shall store food in a manner which adequately
protects such supplies against deterioration, molding, or contamination by flies.
Correct by 6/14/2024

Perimeter fencing along the southwest corner of the property only goes up a maximum of 7.5 feet. The structural integrity
of the fence has been compromised in sections causing the top of the fence to droop in areas and not meet the 8 foot
requirement that this facility needs to have because of the type of animals housed at the facility. Not having the perimeter
fence meet the 8 foot requirement for the potentially dangerous animals they have could result in those animals not being
properly contained if they were to escape from their primary enclosure. The perimeter fence needs to be fixed so all the
outdoor housing facilities containing dangerous animals are completely enclosed by a perimeter fence no less than 8 feet
in height. Correct by 7/12/24.

A tethered peregrine falcon was observed to have its tether tangled to the point that it could not move further than two
inches off the floor. The falcon was tethered to a bow perch and the tether was wrapped around the base of the stand.
The bird was perching on the metal base and appeared to have been in this position for an extended period of time
evidenced by the amount of droppings present on the floor in a semi-circular pattern behind the bird. Due to the
entanglement, the bird was forced to perch on the hard surface of the metal base or on the floor. During the inspection,
the bird was seen lifting its legs to pull at the tether and at times flapped its wings and vocalized. The bird was unable to
reach the water dish and therefore did not have access to water for the period of time it was entangled. Entanglement of
tethered birds could result in injury to the bird. Birds must not be tethered unless the tether does not entangle the bird.
Correct by 6/13/24.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility does not have an environment enhancement plan in place for the birds. Not having an environment
enhancement plan in place doesn't ensure the psychological well-being of the birds. The facility must develop, document,
and follow a species-appropriate plan for all birds in its care. The plan must be approved by the Attending Veterinarian.
Correct by 7/12/24.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
End of report.
Additional Inspectors:
Eric Irvin, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Marla Renshaw, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.81(c)(4) 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
A female lemur was being individually housed in an indoor housing facility. While reviewing the facilities environment 
enhancement plan for NHP it does not appropriately address special considerations for individually housed NHP that 
cannot see or hear NHP of its own or compatible species. The environment enhancement plan was approved by the AV 
when there were 2 lemurs being housed together but has not been updated since the 2nd lemur was removed. Failure to 
provide special attention to individually housed NHPs could result in psychological distress which could negatively affect 
their well-being. Facilities must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan as directed by the attending 
veterinarian for environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of nonhuman primates. 
Correct by 7/12/24. 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
Multiple maintenance issues were observed during inspection. An elevated shelter/den box (approximately 5.5 feet off the 
ground) that a gray fox was sleeping in had flooring that was coming loose and a corner of the flooring was separating 
from the walls with the corner flapping/moving as the fox was breathing. The side of a wolf shelter in an enclosure 
containing 3 wolves had the back wall coming off. The underground fencing in the arctic fox enclosure was washed out 
underneath and there was a gap between the fencing and the ground underneath. The same enclosure also had rabbit 
wire with sharp points protruding from it into the enclosure. Screwheads/nailheads were sticking out on the flooring of 
various wooden resting platforms in multiple fox and bobcat enclosures. An igloo shelter for an enclosure containing 6 
wolves was cracked and had a hole in it. 
 
These maintenance issues create various safety hazards for the animals. The fox could potentially fall through the flooring 
of its shelter as its sleeping. Shelter with holes in it or the walls coming off doesn't properly protect the animals from the 
elements of the weather. The underground fencing with the gap underneath could potentially cause injury if the arctic fox 
stepped through the fencing and got its leg stuck. Sharp points in an enclosure can also cause injury. 
 
All shelter or resting platforms being provided to the animals need to be fixed and maintained so no 
screwheads/nailheads or sharp points are sticking out, no walls or floors are falling off of the provided shelters, and no 
animals can stick their limbs through the underground fencing as they walk through their shelter.

3.125(c) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The walk-in freezer used to store fresh meat products for the carnivores’ showed signs of significant structural damage 
that prevented the freezer from fully closing. There was excessive ice buildup within the freezer further preventing proper 
closure and potentially exposing the food products to temperature fluctuations. Failure to provide adequate refrigeration to 
perishable food can result in spoilage of food which can cause serious food borne illnesses in the animals. Supplies of 
food shall be provided adequate refrigeration by the facility to prevent spoilage and maintain it’s wholesomeness.  
 
At the food donation drop-off site there were three white-tailed deer carcasses in various stages of decomposition. There 
were too numerous to count flies on and around the carcasses with two of the carcasses having visible maggots and 
exposed body cavities. These donated deer carcasses are intended as food for the carnivores and the facility is not 
following their SOP for donated deer meat which requires the carcasses to be cut and immediately stored under 
refrigeration. Failure to store the deer carcasses appropriately is allowing for contamination by flies which can 
contaminate the meat and spread disease to the animals. The facility shall store food in a manner which adequately 
protects such supplies against deterioration, molding, or contamination by flies. 
Correct by 6/14/2024 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
Perimeter fencing along the southwest corner of the property only goes up a maximum of 7.5 feet. The structural integrity 
of the fence has been compromised in sections causing the top of the fence to droop in areas and not meet the 8 foot 
requirement that this facility needs to have because of the type of animals housed at the facility. Not having the perimeter 
fence meet the 8 foot requirement for the potentially dangerous animals they have could result in those animals not being 
properly contained if they were to escape from their primary enclosure. The perimeter fence needs to be fixed so all the 
outdoor housing facilities containing dangerous animals are completely enclosed by a perimeter fence no less than 8 feet 
in height. Correct by 7/12/24. 
3.153(b)(2)(v)  Direct
   
Primary enclosures. 
A tethered peregrine falcon was observed to have its tether tangled to the point that it could not move further than two 
inches off the floor. The falcon was tethered to a bow perch and the tether was wrapped around the base of the stand. 
The bird was perching on the metal base and appeared to have been in this position for an extended period of time 
evidenced by the amount of droppings present on the floor in a semi-circular pattern behind the bird. Due to the 
entanglement, the bird was forced to perch on the hard surface of the metal base or on the floor. During the inspection, 
the bird was seen lifting its legs to pull at the tether and at times flapped its wings and vocalized. The bird was unable to 
reach the water dish and therefore did not have access to water for the period of time it was entangled. Entanglement of 
tethered birds could result in injury to the bird. Birds must not be tethered unless the tether does not entangle the bird. 
Correct by 6/13/24. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.

The facility does not have an environment enhancement plan in place for the birds. Not having an environment 
enhancement plan in place doesn't ensure the psychological well-being of the birds. The facility must develop, document, 
and follow a species-appropriate plan for all birds in its care. The plan must be approved by the Attending Veterinarian. 
Correct by 7/12/24. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative. 
 
End of report. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Eric Irvin, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
Marla Renshaw, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
